_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Club Chef Southeast LLC

4322 Moreland Ave

Conley, GA 30288



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Facility Club Chef Southeast endeavors in all its activities to promote a quality environment. We recognize that activities at this facility may impact our employees and the surrounding community. Because of this, Club Chef Southeast is dedicated to environmental protection, employee health and safety, regulatory compliance and pollution prevention through a strategy of continual improvement and teamwork.



Our company environmental, health, and safety (EHS) policy and requirements promote the overall safety of this facility, our employees, and the public. This policy includes risk reduction programs that provide assurance for the safe management of process risks to prevent environmental, health and safety incidents and to protect the workplace, the community and the environment. Club Chef Southeast is committed to complying with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard, Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119, and EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations,



Title 40 CFR Part 68, to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and processing of hazardous chemicals. These programs enable the facility to prevent the occurrence, or minimize the consequences of, significant releases of anhydrous ammonia.



It is Club Chef Southeast's policy to conduct our business in accordance with all applicable laws, regulations, and permits and to promote a safe workplace and a quality environment. Each employee is trained and required to comply strictly with this policy.



Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled

The Club Chef Southeast is located at 4322 Moreland Ave, Conley, GA 30288 utilizes an anhydrous ammonia (CAS 7664-41-7) refrigeration system to maintain proper storage temperatures for various food and produce items. The refrigeration system i

caused any injuries to employees or impacted any offsite receptors in the past five years.



Emergency Response Program

The facility has in place a variety of emergency response procedures to protect employees, contractors, the public and the environment from hazards associated with accidental releases of regulated substances. The emergency response program is based on OSHA's requirements for emergency action plans (29 CFR 1910.38. The programs consist of procedures for responding to releases of regulated substances, including the possibility of associated fires and/or explosions. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including evacuation plans, accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, if a release occurs. Employees receive periodic training in these procedures to perform emergency response duties. The program receives periodic reviews and is updated as necessary for modifications made to the facility or practices.



The overall emergency response program for the facility is coordinated with the Local Emergency

Planning Committee (LEPC). This coordination includes attending periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials and industry representatives. The facility offers the local fire department and other emergency response organizations the opportunity to participate in periodic emergency response drills.



Facility personnel notify local agencies when emergency response assistance is needed. Local agencies determine if the public needs to be notified. If it is determined that the public needs to be notified, the local agencies perform the notification task.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

In response to the most recent Process Hazard Analysis, the facility plans to implement additional engineering safeguards. These additional safeguards will lessen the risk associated with the process
